ReqHunter

ReqHunter is not user friendly. To use this software you need to implement the ReqHunter API. This API is very simple and straighforward, but as this implementation is required we can say that users of ReqHunter are mostly Java developers or people that know a bit of Java programming. It is a constraint in the usage of the software but hence you can define the structure of your requirements, the format of the references (associated to each requirement) and a lot of things.

The real interest of Reqhunter is to provide a environment for working on the user requirements easily.
Examples of requirements are given Table 1 which contains a requirement from rmtoo and Table 2 which contains a requirement from the RARE project.

Figure 1: A requirement from rmtoo

Figure 2: A requirement from the RARE project

These two type of requirements are very different. First their structures are different, the number of fields and their names. The semantics attached to each field is different. And constraints underlying the values of some fields (as the field "Effort estimation" in Table 1 or the field "Priority" in Table 2) may exists.

ReqHunter is composed of three processes:

  1. context extraction,
  2. requirement management,
  3. applicable document generation.

Figure 4 represents the UML class diagram the three classes to implement.

Figure 3: ReqHunter

To use ReqHunter you need at least two things: (1) a XML schema that represents your requirements, and (2) an implementation of the three classes in Figure 3.

Figure 4: UML class diagram of the ReqHunter API


Subsections
  • Writing a XML schema for your type of requirement
  • Implementation of the API
  • Content extraction
  • Requirements database
  • Applicable documents production
